content.text: Define _acceleration. Explain any symbols in your definition
For the time interval between 40s and 100s, calculate the distance travelled by the train
distance = .........
The train stops for 80s, then accelerates to \(30 \text{m/s}\) with an acceleration of \(0.60 \text{m/s}^2\). It then travels at constant speed
Complete the graph for the interval 100s to 280s, showing your calculations in the space below
Fig. 1.1 shows a graph of speed against time for a train. After 100s the train stops at a station
Energy from the Sun evaporates water from the sea. Some of this water event hydroelectric power station. Give an account of the processes and energy changes
State the two conditions required for the equilibrium of a body acted upon by forces
By taking moments about point P, calculate the force \(F\)
A force acts on the forearm at point P. Calculate this force and state its direction
force =
direction = .........
Fig. 3.1 shows a diagram of an arm with the hand holding a weight of 120 N

The 20 N force is the weight of the forearm, acting at its centre of mass. \(F\) is the force in the muscle of the upper arm. P is the point in the elbow about which the arm pivots. The distances of the forces from point P are shown
Complete Fig. 4.1 to show a simple mercury barometer. Insert the correct
boxes. Label with the letter \(h\) the measurement required to calculate the pressure atmosphere

The value of \(h\) taken using this barometer is \(0.73 \text{m}\). The density of mercury is \(13 600 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). Calculate the value of the atmospheric pressure suggested by this measurement. Use \(g = 10 \text{m} / \text{s}^2\)
atmospheric pressure = .........
Standard atmospheric pressure is \(0.76 \text{m}\) of mercury. Suggest a reason why the value of \(h\) in (b) is lower than this
State which of the three, solid, liquid or gas,
1. expands the most,
2. expands the least
Explain why the pressure of the gas must be kept constant for this comparison
Equal volumes of a gas held at constant pressure, a liquid and a solid under temperature rise
State two properties of alcohol which make it suitable for use in a thermometer
State two changes to the design of this thermometer which would make it more sensitive
Fig. 5.1 shows an alcohol thermometer
Explain why it is an advantage for the glass surrounding the alcohol in the bulb of the thermometer to be very thin

the sound had a higher frequency,
the sound were louder

Fig. 6.1 shows the position of layers of air, at one moment, as a sound wave
frequency passes through the air. Compressions are labelled C. Rarefactions are labelled

In an experiment to measure the speed of sound in steel, a steel pipe of length \(200\mathrm{m}\) is struck at one end with a hammer. A microphone at the other end of the pipe is connected to an accurate timer. The timer records a delay of \(0.544\mathrm{s}\) between the arrival of the sound transmitted by the steel pipe and the sound transmitted by the air in the pipe
The speed of sound in air is \(343 \text{m/s}\). Calculate the speed of sound in steel
speed of sound in steel = .........
Fig. 7.1
State what is meant by monochromatic light
For this red ray the refractive index of the glass is 1.52. Calculate the angle of refraction for the ray
angle of refraction = .........
Without measuring angles, use a ruler to draw the approximate path of the ray in the glass block and emerging from the block
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of monochromatic red light, in air, incident on a glass block a incidence of \(50^{\circ}\)
Calculate the speed of the violet light in the glass block

Use a ruler to draw the approximate path of this violet ray in the glass block and emerging from the block. Make sure this path is separated from the path drawn for the red light in **(a)(iii)**. Mark both parts of this path with the letter V
The red ray in Fig. 7.1 is replaced by a ray of monochromatic violet light. For this refractive index of the glass is 1.54. The speed of light in air is \(3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
In Fig. 8.1, a magnet is moving towards one end of a solenoid connected to a series zero meter. During this movement a current is induced in the solenoid
Suggest **three** possible changes to the system in Fig. 8.1 that would increase the induced current

the voltage of the supply to P,
voltage = .........
the current in P
current = .........
Fig. 8.2 shows a transformer. P is the primary coil. S is the secondary coil. The coils are wound on an iron core
P has 200 turns and S has 800 turns. The e.m.f. induced across S is 24V. The current in S is 0.50A. The transformer operates with 100% efficiency

1. the resistor,

At \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) the resistance of B is \(25\Omega .\)
In terms of the p.d. across B, explain what happens in the circuit as the temperature varies from \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)

the heater,
